üèÜ TLDR Named to Inc.'s 2025 Best in Business List - Best Bootstrapped! üèÜ

We're thrilled to announce that TLDR has been recognized on Inc.'s 2025 Best in Business list in the Best Bootstrapped category.

Inc.'s Best in Business list highlights companies making a meaningful positive impact - on customers, communities, and their industries - while growing in a healthy, disciplined, and sustainable way.

The Bootstrapped category is particularly special. It recognizes companies that have built something exceptional without external funding, proving that world-class businesses can be built through craft, discipline, and delivering value to customers.

This recognition belongs to the people who make TLDR possible:

Our team ‚Äì who raise the bar every day with their craft, speed, and relentless focus on quality - the force that makes TLDR what it is
Our readers ‚Äì for opening, sharing, and trusting TLDR to keep you informed every single day
Our customers and partners ‚Äì for trusting us with their campaigns and growth

Building TLDR has been a journey powered by reader value, customer trust, and sustainable growth. This award validates that approach and reminds us that doing things the right way isn't just possible, it's worth celebrating.
Want to work with us?

Sponsorships: Reach millions of engaged readers through TLDR's newsletters at https://lnkd.in/gGYE2qQu

Careers: Join a team that's building with craft and long-term thinking at https://lnkd.in/gE5DdAEC

Subscribe: Stay ahead of what matters in tech, AI, infosec, crypto and more at https://tldr.tech

Thank you to everyone who's been part of this journey. Onward! üöÄ

#BestInBusiness

data.text:
üéâ  Big news at TLDR üéâ 

Incredibly proud to share that TLDR has been named to Inc.'s 2025 Best in Business list in the Best Bootstrapped category.

This recognition hits different.

We've built TLDR without external funding - growing profitably by serving our readers exceptionally well and staying disciplined in how we operate.

This award validates that approach: focus on quality, focus on value, and build for the long term.

What makes this meaningful is who made it possible:

Our team - Their craftsmanship, speed, and care are the foundation of everything TLDR has become. They prove every day that you can build something world-class without compromising your values.

Our readers - Your trust and engagement fuel everything we do. You're why we show up every day.

Our customers and partners - Thank you for choosing TLDR to reach engaged, high-intent audiences. Your confidence in us drives us forward.

Building TLDR has been one of the most rewarding experiences of my career. This milestone reflects the collective effort of everyone who's been part of the journey, and I'm incredibly grateful.

If you want to partner with TLDR, explore sponsorship opportunities, or join the team, my inbox is open!

resharedPost.text:
This summer, I got a dream assignment: Write a profile of Dan N., the founder of the wildly popular tech newsletter TLDR. Dan's journey is fascinating‚Äîan early career in finance was derailed by a rare medical condition that sent him back home to Missouri for several years. He started TLDR in 2018, but along the way, he started and sold a Saas business and even went to culinary school. Read the full story in Inc. Magazine today! 

Thanks to Michelle Legro for the assignment and to Adam Ryan Andrew Namanny and Andrew Tan for speaking to me for this story, and of course a HUGE thank you to Dan for trusting me to tell his incredible story. 

https://lnkd.in/dSctGBEY

data.text: Thanks Rob Verger for giving me a chance to tell the full backstory behind TLDR for the first time!

Growing a newsletter is hard. Here‚Äôs a trick you can steal from the biggest companies to make it 10x easier:

üöó Uber ‚Äì Tap a button, get a ride.
üé• Netflix ‚Äì Unlimited movies & shows, no ads.
üè° Airbnb ‚Äì Rent unique places from real people.

What do they all have in common? Anyone can explain them in one sentence.

Now, what‚Äôs your newsletter‚Äôs one-liner?

If you can‚Äôt sum up how it‚Äôs different from every other newsletter out there, neither can your audience. And if they can‚Äôt, they won‚Äôt subscribe or share it.

Here's TLDR's: ‚ÄúKeep up with tech in 5 minutes."

Try crafting your own with these templates:
 ‚ÄúThe newsletter that [does X] so you don‚Äôt have to [pain point].‚Äù
‚ÄúThe easiest way to stay on top of [niche topic].‚Äù
‚ÄúIf [big publication] and [another source] had a baby, it‚Äôd be this newsletter.‚Äù

The way people buy today vs. 10 years ago feels like night and day. Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve noticed:

1) Buyers are in control
10 years ago, buyers relied on sales reps to explain everything. Thanks to social media, forums, and newsletters (üëã), people have access to way more peer-driven info. By the time they talk to a sales team, they‚Äôre already 80% of the way to a decision.

2) The trust gap is wider
Buyers are skeptical of social media ads, polished case studies, and flashy demos. Instead, they‚Äôre leaning on recommendations from people they trust‚Äîfriends, colleagues, even strangers on the internet. Social proof has never been more powerful. A single recommendation from a trusted source outweighs 10 ads.

3) Speed is everything
Buyers want quick answers and instant value. The shorter the time to value, the more likely a solution is to stand out and win their attention.

How TLDR grew to 5M subscribers

Spoiler: It wasn‚Äôt because of a lucky viral moment.

We got there by through good ol' steady, compounding growth. 

Here‚Äôs what worked for us:
- Retention, then Acquisition: A loyal audience tells their friends. Focus on keeping people first before prioritizing subscriber growth.
- Quality over quantity: A few great pieces beat a dozen mediocre ones.
- Data-driven iteration: Your audience‚Äôs behavior tells you what they love (and don‚Äôt).

2024 was a big one for us‚Äîarguably the year TLDR became a ‚Äúreal‚Äù company. 

Some highlights:
- Grew the team from 8 to 18 full-timers.
- Made our first hires in demand gen and people ops (s/o Christopher Chan and Brandon Jeffs!).
- Expanded the SDR team from just Monica McIlroy üçµ to a squad of 6.
- Built key foundations: sales forecasting, marketing automation, and a proper recruiting pipeline.
- Over 5.3m subscribers to TLDR newsletters
- 92% YoY revenue growth

For 2025, we‚Äôre doubling down on scaling efficiently:
- Bigger deals, better advertiser recommendations.
- Refining demand gen and subscriber growth funnels.
- Streamlining workflows with engineering.
- And most importantly, making TLDR the best place to work.

I‚Äôve been seeing a lot of posts about "multichannel marketing" lately (and TLDR  has definitely benefitted from marketers going beyond search and social). Wanted to quickly share my thoughts on how to make it work.

You don‚Äôt need to be everywhere to succeed.

Multichannel marketing works best when you focus on the right channels, not all of them. The key is figuring out where to prioritize:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Audience first
Where does your ideal customer naturally spend time? Newsletters, search, podcasts, or social platforms? Start there.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Channel strength
Each channel serves a unique role‚Äîsearch captures intent, newsletters build trust and credibility within a community, podcasts drive depth, and social creates broad awareness. Focus on the ones that align with your goals.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Do fewer things better
If you can only execute two channels well, that‚Äôs still better than being average across five. Nail it, then expand.

TL;DR: Multichannel marketing works when you focus on the right channels for your audience and execute them exceptionally well.

Social media is noisy. Ads get ignored. But newsletters? They cut through all of it.

When someone subscribes to a newsletter, it‚Äôs intentional. They‚Äôre choosing to invite you into their inbox, not just stumbling across you in a chaotic feed. That choice creates unmatched focus.

For creators and marketers, newsletters offer something rare in today‚Äôs world: undivided attention. Your message isn‚Äôt competing with cat memes, trending topics, or endless scrolls. It‚Äôs a direct connection to people who genuinely care about what you have to say.

And when done well‚Äîby respecting your audience‚Äôs time and consistently delivering value‚Äîthis relationship builds trust that‚Äôs hard to replicate anywhere else.

TL;DR: Newsletters aren‚Äôt dying‚Äîthey‚Äôre thriving, because they foster focus and trust in a noisy world.

Started from the inbox, now we‚Äôre here. üöÄ

4 years ago I started TLDR as a side project, for fun. No big vision, no business plan. Just me sharing tech stories I thought were interesting. It was a way to unwind, not something I ever imagined would grow beyond a few readers.

Fast forward to today, and TLDR is on a billboard in Times Square! What started as a fun little side project has turned into something bigger than I ever dreamed of. 

Thank you to the millions of readers who open TLDR every day (seriously, thank you for trusting us with your inbox), and the incredible team behind the scenes who‚Äôve turned this little newsletter into something truly special.

We‚Äôre wired for instant gratification‚Äîscrolling through social feeds, watching 10-second videos, and chasing quick dopamine hits. Your newsletter is competing with this, which means every second counts.

Take TLDR‚Äôs approach to combating short attention spans: 

1. Keep it concise: TLDR curates and summarizes the latest tech stories into a few sentences, just enough to deliver the key points without losing impact. Links provide optional deep dives for curious readers.

2. Organize for clarity: Every newsletter is broken into categories, making it easy for subscribers to jump straight to what they care about. This structure respects their time and attention.

3. Make ads seamless: TLDR integrates ads so they feel native and relevant. Instead of disrupting the experience, they add value.

Your readers don‚Äôt want to dig for value. They want it handed to them‚Äîclearly and quickly. If you don‚Äôt deliver, there‚Äôs always another newsletter that will.

TL;DR: Your newsletter competes with dopamine-driven habits. Be fast, clear, and direct‚Äîor lose the fight for attention.

Creativity gets all the glory in marketing. It‚Äôs the big ideas, the clever campaigns, the viral moments. But you know what really drives results? Showing up. Consistently.

When I started TLDR, I didn‚Äôt have a fancy strategy. But I made one commitment: Show up every weekday, no matter what. That consistency‚Äîsending out a newsletter rain or shine‚Äîbuilt trust over time. Not every issue was perfect, but the habit of showing up is what turned readers into loyal subscribers.

It‚Äôs the same with marketing. A single creative ad might grab attention, but it‚Äôs the repeated exposure‚Äîthe consistency‚Äîthat makes people remember you. Research shows people need to see a brand multiple times before they take action. The same principle applies to content, campaigns, or engagement: Consistency builds trust, keeps you top of mind, and drives results over time.

TL;DR: Creativity grabs attention, but consistency is what makes people remember you and builds trust.

‚ÄúAre newsletters oversaturated?‚Äù

I hear this question all the time, and honestly, it makes me laugh. Not because it‚Äôs a bad question‚Äîbut because it assumes the answer matters.

Let‚Äôs flip it around: are podcasts oversaturated? Is YouTube oversaturated? What about blogs? Every medium looks crowded if you focus on the average. But here‚Äôs the thing: the best ones still break through.

At TLDR, we‚Äôve grown to millions of subscribers by zeroing in on what tech professionals actually want‚Äîconcise updates on the most important tech news and trends. It‚Äôs not magic; it‚Äôs about obsessing over your audience and making sure you‚Äôre delivering consistent value they can‚Äôt get anywhere else.

The key isn‚Äôt the medium‚Äîit‚Äôs the execution. Understand your audience, deliver something unique, and stay consistent. That‚Äôs how you rise above the noise.

When it comes to choosing what goes into TLDR, I use a simple filter:

Would I share this with friends or colleagues?

If it‚Äôs not worth sharing in a quick text or Slack message, it‚Äôs not worth sending out to hundreds of thousands of readers.

This approach is one of the reasons why TLDR maintains a 40%+ open rate‚Äîeven with over 5M subscribers.

By sticking to content that‚Äôs relevant and valuable, we make sure readers actually look forward to each issue.

TL;DR: Curate content like you‚Äôre sending it to a friend‚Äîit‚Äôs the ultimate quality test.

Want your exec team active on LinkedIn? Share this post with them. My marketing team challenged me to post for 90 days straight. Here are the results:

‚Ä¢ 239k organic impressions
‚Ä¢ 1.6k+ new followers (almost doubling my follower count)
‚Ä¢ Advertisers mentioning hearing about TLDR on LinkedIn increased from 11 (baseline) in August to 23 last month

We also turn our most engaging posts into Thought Leadership ads targeting tech marketers (our ICP), seeing ~15% CTR compared to an average ~0.45% (this metric is inflated by "see more" clicks). Dwell time is about 2x longer.

3 key learnings:

1. Write for your audience, not just for impressions or follower growth

2. Topical relevance is everything - I started receiving more DMs, and more marketers mentioned LinkedIn on our inbound form after we pivoted our content strategy to focus on learnings from TLDR's growth to 5 million subs and tips on newsletter advertising.

3. Strong hooks are crucial - you're competing with thousands of posts for a few seconds of attention.

4. Posts of 150-200 words works best for me, though others have found success with longer formats.

tl;dr: If your audience is on LinkedIn, it's worth being active here.

What Gergely Orosz can teach every marketer about content distribution: 

For those who don‚Äôt know Gergely, he‚Äôs a former Uber Engineering manager who writes The Pragmatic Engineer, the top tech newsletter on Substack.

He also runs a podcast, a blog and he puts out some killer content on LinkedIn and Twitter.

Here‚Äôs what he gets right:

> He‚Äôs authentic ‚Äî every post sounds the same as he talks on his podcast, no flashy language to try and feed the algorithm. 

> He creates differentiated content ‚Äî he doesn‚Äôt just go for broad tech news, he dives into software specifics that he has the expertise to unpack.

> He doesn‚Äôt shy away from weighing in on hot-button issues ‚Äî some of his best posts are about the biggest failures of major tech companies, even ones he‚Äôs worked for!

> He doesn‚Äôt cross into click-bait territory ‚Äî¬†no forced edginess or controversy, he just gets straight to the facts and his takeaways. 

tl;dr: Want to win at content? Write like Gergely Orosz ‚Äî authentic, expertise-oriented, and just the right amount of edgy.

The era of only advertising on search and social is over. 

Here‚Äôs why:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Increased Scrutiny
Companies are looking at ad spend closer than ever ‚Äî ditching ‚Äúgrow at all costs‚Äù and prioritizing platforms with the best ROI. 

2Ô∏è‚É£ Advanced Attribution Tools
Thanks to platforms like HockeyStack, spotting wasted ad spend is easier than ever. 

3Ô∏è‚É£ Rise of Trusted Channels
The winners here are the distribution channels that have built trust and credibility within communities‚Äîthink newsletters, podcasts, and influencers‚Äîwhere ad dollars are inherently more effective.

We‚Äôve seen this at TLDR ‚Äî we have more sponsor interest than ever before.

The better attribution gets for channels like ours, the more ad dollars we‚Äôll see flow in.

tl;dr: Don‚Äôt just rely on search and social. Open up your ad strategy to spaces that deliver more than reach alone.

Creating a newsletter is easier than ever ‚Äî but truth is, they haven‚Äôt really been that hard to make for over a decade. 

With platforms like Beehiiv and Substack, launching is practically plug-and-play. But even more than 10 years ago, folks were already creating newsletters without code using tools like Mailchimp.

But gaining real traction? That‚Äôs always been the hard part.

Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve learned scaling TLDR: 

***You need to find product-market fit with your newsletter just like you would any other product***

Same applies to pretty much any type of marketing content you‚Äôre putting out there. 

It doesn‚Äôt matter how good it is if it‚Äôs going to an audience that doesn‚Äôt have a real need for it.

tl;dr: PMF applies to more than what its first letter stands for. To create content that resonates, identify and meet a specific need‚Äîjust like you would with a software product.

Marketers ask our team this question all the time: ‚ÄúHow does TLDR compare to ___ newsletter?‚Äù 

Guess what? No two newsletters are the same!

There‚Äôs a big misconception that newsletters are all competing with each other.

But here‚Äôs the reality:

Newsletters are like unique products‚Äîeach one created for a specific audience or to offer something fresh.

At TLDR, our goal is to be tech‚Äôs paper of record.

We‚Äôre doing this by sharing our perspective on what‚Äôs truly interesting in the tech world and delivering that to our audience of 5M+ subscribers.

Sure, we‚Äôre part of the newsletter world, but our mission and audience are entirely our own.

tl;dr: Find the newsletters that align with your brand and audience. Treat each as a unique channel rather than competition. That‚Äôs the key to making your ad campaigns really work.

üëâ Want to build repeat audiences, create feedback loops, and drive a narrative?

Start a newsletter.

üëâ Want to rank on Google?

Start with a blog, and target what top results don‚Äôt address. Or, better yet, repurpose newsletter archives as blog posts.

tl;dr: Newsletters keep your fans coming back; blogs get them in the door. Leverage whichever fits your growth goals.

Pro tip: A ton of marketers are reaching out and wanting to learn more about newsletter advertising (Q4 and yearly targets definitely has marketers looking at all options!).

Most only ask about our audience, but they should really be looking for all 3 of these: 

1Ô∏è‚É£ Audience alignment

As with any channel, their target audience should match your own. Don‚Äôt waste time reaching the wrong people. (And if you're not clear on your ICP yet, figure that out before advertising).

2Ô∏è‚É£ Content alignment 

Ads that feel relevant and integrated into the newsletter's theme tend to perform better. How do you test that? Easy. Subscribe first and get a feel for the content and tone. 

3Ô∏è‚É£ True partnership

Your relationship with the newsletter should feel collaborative. Don‚Äôt be shy about asking for metrics (think open rates, CTRs, subscriber growth) and if they‚Äôll write your copy for you (this saves you time and boosts ad resonance).

From the moment someone clicks your ad to the point they make a purchase, your job is to reduce friction wherever possible. 

At TLDR here's how we do that:

‚û°Ô∏è Case studies: So marketers can gain a sense of how their ads can perform, reducing the risk of buyer‚Äôs remorse.

‚û°Ô∏è Ad copywriting: We handle all copywriting for our sponsors to match our editorial voice and ensure consistency.

‚û°Ô∏è Customer success team: Our best-in-class team helps advertisers stay within budget and ensures campaigns run smoothly. With each client, we actively learn what strategy works best for their specific product and improve it with each subsequent campaign.

Impressions have dropped month over month since I started posting in August. But get this: TLDR has seen a steady increase in advertisers mentioning they heard about us through LinkedIn every single month!

# of mentions
Aug: 11
Sep: 14
Oct: 19 (and we still have one week left to go!)

So, what changed? We pivoted our content strategy.

Instead of writing for impressions, we focused on the topics that mattered to marketers:
- How TLDR grew from 0 to 5 million subscribers
- Messaging and content insights from my experience and our work with TLDR's advertisers

Key lessons here:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Write for your audience, not just for the most impressions
2Ô∏è‚É£ Topical relevance is everything

Thinking about it a bit more, TLDR‚Äôs curators have mastered these lessons. It's why our content connects so deeply with tech professionals.

üí• When we hit the 100,000 subscriber mark, we knew TLDR was something special.

Something was telling us that we weren‚Äôt just reaching our target audiences, we were actually resonating with them.

What was it? Well, it was actually two things: unsolicited positive feedback and sponsorship offers. 

That‚Äôs when it clicked: We had unlocked real product-market fit. 

This wasn‚Äôt just my fun side project anymore ‚Äî it was a full-fledged media company that people really cared about. 

I‚Äôm curious to hear from other builders and marketers: What was your PMF unlock moment?

Was it hitting a certain number of users? Was it a specific rave review? 

tl;dr: Whatever form it takes, palpable excitement about your product is how you know you‚Äôve struck PMF gold.

Keep it relevant. Keep it valuable.

That‚Äôs my very simple yet highly effective advice for dev-focused content creation. 

Devs aren‚Äôt just going to consume anything you throw at them ‚Äî they‚Äôre on the hunt for highly technical and practical info. 
 
At TLDR, we‚Äôve learned that adapting content for different subgroups within the developer ecosystem is key. 

How do we do that? We hire curators who work in every vertical.

Every day, our web dev newsletter is put together by a dev from Google and a dev from Meta. Same idea holds for every other newsletter we put out. 

So far, it‚Äôs worked pretty well. Just ask our 5M+ subscribers. üòâ

The so-called ‚Äúseamless‚Äù features everyone raves about might actually be killing your UX and down-funnel conversion metrics. At TLDR , we learned that the hard way.

When we let users subscribe to our newsletters via Twitter or GitHub, things got‚Ä¶ messy.

The UX was terrible when linked through a mobile app. Instead of launching a user‚Äôs default browser where they were already logged in, it would open up an in-app browser and force them to go through the entire sign-in flow for their Google/GitHub/Twitter all over again.

Basically, it didn‚Äôt make things any easier, and we didn‚Äôt see it moving the needle on conversions whatsoever. 

The lesson learned? Simplicity beats ‚Äúcool‚Äù features every time ‚Äî especially when your audience are tech-savvy and won‚Äôt hesitate to jump ship if they‚Äôre caught in the sign-up loop from hell. 

Today, we use a simple email input box on our homepage with a big shiny ‚Äúsubscribe‚Äù button next to it.

Simple. Easy. And most importantly, much appreciated by our audience. 

tl;dr: The last thing you want to create for a tech-savvy audience is frustration ‚Äî they have enough of that as is. When you‚Äôre optimizing for conversions, prioritize *real* simplicity.

How do you stay focused on what matters *most*?

An example from TLDR:

Our readers are constantly asking us to cover new topics. 

Instead of trying to cover everything (a surefire way to fail), here‚Äôs how we think about expansion:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Is this a technical field where expertise matters?

Our readers crave content that traditional journalists alone couldn‚Äôt produce. 

2Ô∏è‚É£ Is this field innovating fast enough?

A newsletter that can keep folks up to speed with a broad range of advancements is an automatic value-add.

3Ô∏è‚É£ How can we gauge demand?

Before we launch new newsletters, we build up a waitlist to test if our bet was right. 

tl;dr: Keep your focus by being audience-centric. Your go-to-market motion in particular becomes a lot more successful when you use their needs, preferences, and pain points as your guiding principles.

5M+ subscribers‚Ä¶ 

That‚Äôs about 7x the population of SF! 

It‚Äôs hard to wrap my head around that number when, just a few years ago, I couldn‚Äôt believe when TLDR hit 100,000.

Back then, it was still just my side hustle ‚Äî software developer by day, solo newsletter curator by night. 

While a lot has changed since then, the early growth lessons haven‚Äôt left me.

Here are the top 3 I credit our success to: 

1Ô∏è‚É£ Keeping it simple

At the beginning, reducing even the smallest friction points matter ‚Äî like having the cursor already in the email input box when the page loads. 

2Ô∏è‚É£ Finding budget-friendly ad channels

Organic growth is great, but it doesn‚Äôt happen automatically. For TLDR, newsletter swaps and ads on Reddit and Quora were effective ways to drive early adoption. 

3Ô∏è‚É£ Holding tight to a long-term vision 

It‚Äôs what took me from solo curating to leading a team of experts across 10 newsletters.

At TLDR, we‚Äôve managed to achieve industry-leading open rates of 40%+ across all of our newsletters.

And our average reader is subscribed to more than 2 of them‚Ä¶  

Here‚Äôs how we do it:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Each newsletter focuses on a niche technical topic 

We let readers opt in and out of specific newsletters based on their own interests ‚Äî a much better approach than trying to get overly broad content to appeal to everyone. 

2Ô∏è‚É£ We‚Äôve nailed content

The best content comes from trusted voices. That‚Äôs why all of ours is curated by field practitioners. Our web dev newsletter? 100% written by engineers at Meta and Google. Our AI team? Every single member has either worked at Google or OpenAI. 
 
2Ô∏è‚É£ We automatically unsubscribe readers who don‚Äôt open a newsletter after 60 days. 

You shouldn‚Äôt be sending emails to people who never read them!

tl;dr: When it comes to content, only give your audience what they want ‚Äî that means in terms of topics AND the voices behind each output.

If you don‚Äôt have any organic growth, you‚Äôre in real trouble. 

Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve learned over the last few years scaling TLDR:

Organic growth ‚Äî driven by things like word-of-mouth, referral programs, and social posting ‚Äî is a sign of true value and sustainable success. It reflects the kind of deeper connection with the customer that‚Äôs crucial for keeping them engaged long-term. 

Then there‚Äôs inorganic growth.

Paid marketing can definitely help give you a boost, but it only works when you have a true understanding of your business‚Äô unit economics ‚Äî think customer lifetime value, acquisition cost, and payback period.

Without that knowledge, the only result paid ads are going to deliver is wasted ad dollars. 

tl;dr: Organic growth is your business‚Äôs lifeblood. Paid advertising is a growth ‚Äúnice to have‚Äù ‚Äî but only if it‚Äôs grounded in a thorough understanding of the business that an organic approach provides.

Want ultra-targeted leads without breaking the bank? Start answering questions on Reddit and Quora.

That‚Äôs a large part of how I scaled ScraperAPI from a one-man operation to a 7-figure business. 

Just think about how many devs add ‚ÄúReddit‚Äù to the end of the hyper-specific questions they type into Google‚Ä¶ 

Here‚Äôs how I capitalized on that:

- Engaged in any subreddit I could find about web scraping and the problem our tool was solving
- Tried to be genuinely helpful, not just salesy

The number of leads wasn‚Äôt huge. But the quality? Top-notch. 

And all for free!

tl;dr: If you want leads that convert, engage in the niche channels where devs are already searching for the solution you provide.

I previously mentioned how our marketing team doubled conversion rates by cutting form fields in half. Naturally, we tested reducing our fields to just one‚Äîhere's what happened:

Reducing the number of fields from 8 to 4 more than doubled our conversion rates.

Reducing the fields from 4 to 1 resulted in an additional ~30% increase, but with a significant drop in lead quality.

Folks were submitting without any serious intent to advertise with us.

The lesson?

Find the balance between volume and quality. 

Had we only measured form submission rates, we would have called the test a success, while sending low quality leads to our sales team.

tl;dr: When running form conversion tests, measure the downstream impact of your changes. Find the balance between volume and quality.

Devs are drowning in newsletters üì®

Morning Brew, Tech Crunch, smaller niche options ‚Äî the list is endless. 

It‚Äôs no surprise that advertisers are constantly asking us how TLDR  is different from the rest. 

Here‚Äôs something to think about beyond audience and open rates: trusted voices. 

At TLDR, our web dev newsletter is written by engineers at Meta and Google.

Our crypto newsletter? All done by two Coinbase employees and a crypto founder. 

Our AI team? Every single member has either worked at Google or OpenAI. 

Devs know when they‚Äôre hearing from someone like them. Trusted voices cut through the noise and get subscribers to connect with newsletters (and their ads), not just read them. 

tl;dr: If you're new to newsletter marketing, read and subscribe to each one before advertising in them. On top of finding newsletters with readers in your target market, find ones that have already built trust with those readers.

I could have started TLDR  on any medium. So why a newsletter? 

The answer‚Äôs pretty simple: incentives.

With a newsletter, high-quality content isn‚Äôt optional.

Having people subscribe to your content, rather than stumble upon it through Google, means you‚Äôre forced to play an iterated game ‚Äî not just a single stage one. 

That‚Äôs why there‚Äôs no newsletter equivalent to the SEO mills that only exist to flood search results with useless content. 

The incentives are totally different ‚Äî and a lot more rewarding on the newsletter side if you ask me. üòâ

tl;dr: Newsletters incentivize playing the long game. You‚Äôre not just creating content to rank‚Äîyou‚Äôre building relationships, iterating on value, and keeping your audience hungry for more.

As a developer and a founder, I see a TON of ads everyday. Very few are memorable and interest me enough to click..

So, for all the marketers targeting people like me, I thought it‚Äôd be helpful if I shared an example of what I think is a great ad vs. a bad one.

This Twilio ad is amazing. 

Within a few seconds I understand the message it‚Äôs trying to convey: it communicates the ubiquity of the tool among the developer community to the non-technical folks involved in the buying process.

A bad ad on the other hand‚Ä¶well, I struggled to come up with an example. And that‚Äôs the point‚Äîyou can‚Äôt remember them!

The takeaway here is: Make your ad memorable. 

tl;dr: When it comes to advertising, don‚Äôt try to call out every feature and benefit‚Äîjust go for something memorable.

Many of today‚Äôs startups are making the exact same messaging mistake I made a few years ago. Here‚Äôs the messaging test that failed to attract developers and (hopefully) you can learn from.

At ScraperAPI we had messaging centered around managing proxies and CAPTCHAs. 

But that wasn‚Äôt what people were buying our product for. 

What they were buying was the major pain point ScraperAPI solved - being able to scrape any page with a simple API call.

This is the exact same mistake AI startups are making today with talking too much about LLMs and not enough about the things customers actually care about.

tl;dr: Messaging should focus on the benefits, not the implementation or features.

tl;dr: Founder mode only works if every leader in the org is in ‚Äúfounder mode‚Äù. Every leader should be technical enough to make decisions themselves. 

"Founder mode‚Äù ‚Äî an incredibly important concept, but also an incredibly poorly named one.

Here‚Äôs how I see it: 

Being in ‚Äúfounder mode‚Äù is important for 2 reasons:

1Ô∏è‚É£ When leaders are hands-on enough, they don‚Äôt push decision making further down the chain.

2Ô∏è‚É£ When they‚Äôre sufficiently technical, they can make those decisions with confidence. 

But here‚Äôs why it‚Äôs misnamed:

1Ô∏è‚É£ The idea isn‚Äôt exclusive to founders ‚Äî it applies to every level of leadership within the org. If the founder is the only leader in ‚Äúfounder mode‚Äù, it‚Äôs not going to work. 

2Ô∏è‚É£ It‚Äôs really more about the overarching Elon Musk view of the world (technical leaders making fast decisions) vs the Jack Welch legacy corporate view of the world (decentralized decision making, which today is just code for diffuse responsibility).

tl;dr: Brand marketing isn‚Äôt just for consumer goods. No matter how you monitor it, step back from the zoomed-in view and think about how you‚Äôre seen from the outside. 

I know a lot of dev marketers still think brand marketing is useless. That‚Äôs easy to say when you‚Äôre knee-deep in info on your own niche industry. 

When you know all 50+ of your competitors along with their strengths and weaknesses, you‚Äôre too close to the problem. 

But what do developers see? Do they know what you‚Äôre doing differently or better? Is your brand really top of mind? 

That‚Äôs what dev marketers need to be thinking about.

tl;dr: Finding external advocates for your product is one of the most foolproof ways to build developer trust. If you‚Äôre generous enough with your incentives, loyal customers don‚Äôt just become endorsers ‚Äî  they become revenue-generating machines.

Your biggest fans could be generating 10% of your revenue.

At ScraperAPI, our affiliate program did just that by converting loyal users into top salespeople.

Here‚Äôs how we spotted the opportunity:

We realized that a lot of our customers would outsource web scraping tasks to freelance software engineers who would use the same tool over and over again for different companies. 

That left us with a great opportunity to build relationships with those freelancers who had the potential to bring us more and more new customers over time. 

Here‚Äôs how we did it in practice: 

It‚Äôs super simple. We offered killer incentives to everyone involved:

-25% recurring commissions for affiliates 
-10% first-month discount for the new customers they referred

Because our product was well-designed and easy to use, freelancers were happy to recommend us over and over again.

tl;dr: Quick win to boost your conversion rates without losing out on data: use data enrichment. 

If you‚Äôre not taking advantage of data enrichment, you‚Äôre doing marketing on hard-mode. 

Here‚Äôs an example from TLDR üëá

Lengthy forms were killing our submission rates. Using data enrichment, we were able to cut down our form from 8 fields to 4 and more than doubled our conversion rates. 

(We actually tested reducing fields down to 1 but I'll save that for another post).

We used to ask for first name, last name, company name (like most companies do).

But by adding an enrichment tool to the mix (we use Apollo), all we needed was a submitter‚Äôs work email to get all of that information and then some. 

Lead conversion rates skyrocketed ‚Äî all thanks to the simplicity that one enrichment tool allowed us to offer our users.

tl;dr: Not every ad channel is going to deliver results. Don‚Äôt be afraid to cut the cord on the underperformers before they drain your budget.

Ever invested in a channel that just didn‚Äôt work out?

If you‚Äôre a dev marketer, your answer‚Äôs most likely yes. 

At ScraperAPI, Google Ads was a total bust.

We tried. We spent. We waited for results that never came. Outside of branded searches, it was a total disaster.

It was a stark reminder that not every channel ‚Äî no matter how popular ‚Äî is always worth the spend. While I‚Äôm a big believer in the idea that growth doesn‚Äôt happen overnight, you need to know when it‚Äôs time to jump ship before you drain your whole ad budget. 

Our problem at ScraperAPI was that we were building a product that devs didn‚Äôt quite know to even search for yet. 

Hindsight's 20/20, but I wish we‚Äôd poured all that AdWords spend into channels that *actually* helped devs understand our product ‚Äî like Quora, Reddit, and other dev communities ‚Äî instead of holding out for a payoff that simply wasn‚Äôt coming. 

tl;dr: Not every ad channel is going to deliver results. Don‚Äôt be afraid to cut the cord on the underperformers before they drain your budget.

‚ÄúWhat do you wish you‚Äôd done differently?‚Äù

I get that question all the time.

As we get into 2025 marketing planning, I think it‚Äôs pretty relevant to talk about. 

Looking back (I know, hindsight‚Äôs always 20/20), there are a couple channels that would have been relatively low effort that I wish we‚Äôd invested more time into: 

1) Social
It‚Äôs become 100x more important as a distribution mechanism in the B2B space. Just building my presence on LinkedIn a year ago would have made a world of difference.

2) SEO
Back in 2018, there was still a lot of low-hanging fruit. High-value keywords had low competition, and the landscape wasn‚Äôt yet saturated with AI-generated content.

Question to my dev marketers out there: What initiatives are you thinking of investing in next?

tl;dr: As you plan for 2025, take a step back from your usual channels and look for untapped, low-hanging opportunities that could bring high returns. If you haven't started building an organic social presence, now is the time!

How does TLDR  maintain industry-leading email open rates of 40%+?

It‚Äôs not magic‚Äîjust smart subject lines. 

Here‚Äôs our approach:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Keep it short: Email clients generally cut off subject lines at 55-60 characters. We aim for under 50 so they display well on mobile.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Maximize impact: Think of it as an exercise in compression. Pack as much value as you can into the fewest number of characters.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Avoid clickbait titles: They might get you one open, but they destroy trust for the emails to follow. 

The result? Interesting subject lines that get people genuinely excited to see what‚Äôs inside.

tl;dr: Capturing your target audience‚Äôs interest and trust from the beginning is crucial‚Äîespecially when they‚Äôre devs. Strike the balance with your email subject lines to start off on the right foot.

Are you spending too much time worrying about attribution? Sure, you need to know what‚Äôs working‚Äîbut chasing 100% accuracy is a time sink. The truth is, you‚Äôre never going to have the complete picture, and that‚Äôs okay.

At TLDR, we‚Äôve found a balance. (For context, we get hundreds of inquiries each month from tech companies eager to sponsor ads in our newsletters.)

Here‚Äôs how we approach it:

1) Software-reported attribution: Basic, but effective. First and last click sources help us get a general sense of what‚Äôs working.

2) Self-reported attribution: We ask potential sponsors how they found us and use ChatGPT to organize their responses. This helps us get insights into ‚Äúdirect‚Äù and ‚Äúorganic‚Äù leads and identify trends in a way that works for us.

What have we found? Most come from socials, referrals, or are existing TLDR subscribers.

We‚Äôre not obsessing over perfect data‚Äîwe just need ‚Äúgood enough‚Äù to make informed decisions that move the needle.

tl;dr: Don‚Äôt let attribution eat up your time. Get to a place where it‚Äôs good enough for your business, and then focus on strategies that drive growth.

My marketing team convinced me to post for 90 days straight. 30 days in, I wanted to share a few takeaways thus far:

Results: 134k impressions, 1,000+ followers, 19 mentions of "LinkedIn" in self-reported attribution (though hard to tell if any is a result of my posts), 16% avg. CTR boosting my top posts via Thought Leadership Ads   

1. Writing on LinkedIn is a completely different beast than writing a newsletter

2. Post reach is at the mercy of the algorithm. Even your most engaged followers might not see every post. This is a stark contrast to newsletters, where you control distribution, and subscribers always receive your email.

3. More engagement on LinkedIn drives more impressions, but doesn‚Äôt guarantee more followers.

4. Content matters more than timing. I haven‚Äôt seen a huge difference in reach based on the time that I post.

5. Still fine-tuning post length, but 150-200 words seems to be the sweet spot. Anything longer starts to lose traction. Short and sharp wins here.

6. Posting external links (even in comments) or using Thought Leadership ads may hurt organic reach. LinkedIn prefers content that keeps users on the platform.

If you've been reading my posts, I'd love your feedback!

tl;dr: 6 key learnings from posting on LinkedIn for 30 days straight - LinkedIn demands strong hooks due to high competition, post reach depends heavily on the algorithm, engagement boosts impressions but doesn‚Äôt always convert to followers, timing seems to be less important than content quality, shorter posts perform best, external links may impact organic reach.

If 100% of your tests succeed, you‚Äôre not truly testing.

This is probably my No. 1 takeaway from scaling two very different businesses.

Here‚Äôs why: A good portion of your tests failing is the sign of a healthy experimentation process.

Whether it's your marketing strategy or a product feature, if every test is succeeding, you're likely focusing on the wrong metrics or not aiming high enough in your experiments.

Being a founder has made for a busy last few years. 

Fortunately, my journey of serial entrepreneurship has coincided with the rise of some pretty great AI tools.

They‚Äôve been particularly helpful as I‚Äôve transitioned from developer to someone trying to connect with both devs and dev marketer audiences‚Äîwhich is harder than it sounds!

Here are a few of the ones that have helped me and my team lighten the load:
Fathom - AI Meeting Assistant: A lifesaver for recording calls and automatically transcribing them
ChatGPT: The good ol‚Äô reliable
CustomGPTs: Pre-configured prompts with added context for our non-technical team members
We‚Äôve also built a number of internal workflows on top of OpenAI‚Äôs API directly (especially within our outbound sales org)

These tools don‚Äôt just save us time, they help us focus on what matters ‚Äî and all the parts of running a tech-focused media company that CAN‚ÄôT be automated (like building user trust).

tl;dr: AI can‚Äôt do your job for you, but it sure can make things easier.

One of my favorite dev marketing stories over the last 10 years: How IPInfo used Stack Overflow to drive millions of developers to their product. 

If you want the whole story from their blog (~6min read), I'll link to it in the comments.

Here are my key takeaways:

1) Dev marketing becomes a whole lot easier when you put yourself in the right places.

Spaces like Stack Overflow are basically giant repositories of people with urgent problems that need solving. That makes it a whole lot easier to find that ‚Äúright place right time‚Äù sweet spot for your messaging. 

2) If you offer solutions because you genuinely want to help, it won‚Äôt feel like marketing at all. 

This was a huge unlock for me while building ScraperAPI. I built the product because it solved one of my own pain points. Devs appreciated that. 

I‚Äôve kept that same philosophy at TLDR ‚Äî the closer we get to becoming tech‚Äôs paper of record, the more effective we become to our advertising partners. 

tl;dr: Dev marketing takes a unique approach. If you want to nail your GTM like IPInfo, find the niche spaces where devs are already congregating and come from a place of genuinely wanting to help.

article.title: I Answered 99 Stack Overflow Questions and Now...
article.subtitle: ipinfo.io

data.text:
I‚Äôve written quite a bit about driving TLDR‚Äôs early growth. But what about once we passed the 100k subscriber mark?

That was a critical turning point on our path to 5M+ subscribers today. 

Here‚Äôs why: 

Crossing 100k meant we finally had the monetization to professionalize our growth operation. That meant bringing in folks to optimize just about everything (sales, marketing, revops, etc.). 

It was a huge shift from the early days when the marketing mix ‚Äî which I was handling completely solo ‚Äî looked a lot more scrappy. Think:
- Personal posts about TLDR
- Sharing info w/ ScraperAPI users
- Relying on word of mouth
- Shoutouts from other newsletters
- Some very bare bones Reddit & Quora ads

That early organic push got us to the milestone it needed to, but the real hockey stick growth came when I‚Ä¶
a) Acknowledged I could no longer do everything myself if I wanted TLDR to grow efficiently  
b) Had enough $ (thanks to that early scrappiness) to find someone who knew growth as well as I knew software development 

tl;dr: Early growth is crucial, but so is your first major inflection point. Once you can, bring in the right resources to supercharge your growth engine.

TLDR ü§ù Tech Marketing Teams

Excited that our case studies and testimonials are now live on our website! Explore how we‚Äôve partnered with companies like Bland AI, Redact, and Drata to achieve success.

Here‚Äôs what Flo Merian, Developer Marketing Expert and co-maintainer of the Developer Marketing Community, had to say:

‚ÄúHonestly, TLDR was 10x better than any of the other channels we explored.‚Äù

‚≠ê Check it out : https://lnkd.in/dAMZX-hq

author.headline: Helping Companies Market to Founders, Execs, and Business Leaders in Tech, Programming, AI, Marketing, Startups, Crypto, and beyond through high-impact TLDR newsletters.

data.text:
In my first 20 months working on it, I grew TLDR from 0 to 130k subscribers. 

One of the biggest things that helped me? Being all about the data ‚Äî something I picked up in my earlier days building ScraperAPI.

Devs and other technical folks talk with their actions. It‚Äôs the job of the marketer to go deep in the data and figure out what they‚Äôre saying.

Here are a few places to start:

1) Mobile landing page interactions

In the early days of TLDR, we saw a lot of traffic coming to our landing page but a comparatively low signup rate.

Improving our page speed by caching via CloudFlare and automatically focusing the cursor in the email input feed were all we needed to send signups skyrocketing. 

2) Content A/B testing

At ScraperAPI, we tested and compared a bunch of different content before landing on one type that worked really well: web scraping with [Blank], Web Scraping with Scrapy (a popular Python framework), Web Scraping with NodeJS (Javascript), etc. There is this interesting phenomenon in developer SEO where a generic term like web scraping might be super competitive, but a more specific version of the term that‚Äôs still quite popular might be super easy to rank for, like web scraping with python.

I‚Äôve been doing the same with all these LinkedIn posts. The longer-form content I was putting out at first wasn‚Äôt getting the resonance I wanted, so I‚Äôm trying my best to keep these short and to the point!
  
3) Feature usage

At ScraperAPI, we didn‚Äôt just check API usage, we checked it by domain scraped and optimized for our most used domains.

We also looked at our support tickets and saw which languages were most commonly used then built SDKs for them.

4) Conversion tracking

Think time to first successful API call (which is what we used at Scraper), or any other KPI that your onboarding flow centers around.

tl;dr: Developers talk the loudest with their actions, and almost all of those actions are trackable. Treat the data points they give you like a goldmine.
